diagnosis.priorTreatmentSummary: Maximal safe surgical resection (05/08/2025) by Dr. David Chang (Neurosurgery)
diagnosis.vascularInvolvement: No vascular involvement noted on imaging.
diagnosis.priorProcedures: Initial diagnostic lumbar puncture (05/09/2025) which was negative for CSF dissemination. Surgical placement of ventriculoperitoneal shunt (05/08/2025) for hydrocephalus management.

treatmentPlan.modality: External Beam Radiation Therapy (EBRT) - Craniospinal Irradiation (CSI) with involved field boost.
treatmentPlan.rtRxDetails: 23.4 Gy in 13 fractions to Craniospinal Axis, followed by 30.6 Gy in 17 fractions boost to Posterior Fossa (Total 54 Gy to Posterior Fossa)
treatmentPlan.targetVolumeSummary: Whole brain and spine (to bottom of thecal sac) for CSI; Posterior Fossa for boost.
treatmentPlan.techniqueSummary: 3D-CRT with gapped abutting fields for craniospinal axis, followed by 3D-CRT for posterior fossa boost. Proton therapy considered but not available.
treatmentPlan.concurrentChemo: None (Vincristine omitted per NCCN guidelines for adults)
treatmentPlan.detailedConcurrentChemo: N/A (no concurrent chemotherapy given for this treatment phase)
medications: Dexamethasone 2 mg PO BID (Tapering schedule planned)
therapistAlerts: Monitor for signs of fatigue and myelosuppression.
Monitor skin integrity along posterior neck/spine where fields abut for potential irritation.
Consideration for sedation during treatment delivery due to patient's age and need for precise immobilization, though not currently utilized.

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Prone, head neutral in custom Aquaplast mask indexed to table, arms abducted above head for craniospinal setup. Patient aligned to room lasers using anterior and bilateral marks.
ctSimulation.immobilization: Custom Aquaplast thermoplastic mask, prone belly board, knee/ankle immobilization.
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: Tattoos placed per protocol. Isocenter for CSI set at Cranial: V+0.0, L+0.0, S+10.0 relative to CT sim reference point. Spine fields aligned to specific vertebral bodies with appropriate superior/inferior gaps.
ctSimulation.ctNotes: Contrast-enhanced CT acquired in treatment position for CSI and boost planning. Patient tolerated prone position well for duration of scan.

dosimetry.planStatus: Final - Approved by Dr. Emily Roberts
dosimetry.rx: CSI: 23.4 Gy / 13 fx; PFB Boost: 30.6 Gy / 17 fx (Total 54 Gy to Posterior Fossa)
dosimetry.technique: 3D-CRT (CSI with abutted fields, PFB boost with 3D fields)
dosimetry.numberOfFieldsOrArcs: Multiple fields for CSI; multiple fields for boost
dosimetry.gantryAngles: CSI: PA (180), Right Lat (270), Left Lat (90); PFB: AP (0), Right Lat (90), Left Lat (270).
dosimetry.collAngles: Adjusted for field matching along spinal axis. Varies per field.
dosimetry.isoCoords: CSI: V+0.0, L+0.0, S+10.0 (Cranial); PFB: V+0.0, L+0.0, S-5.0 (Relative to PFB center).
dosimetry.constraints: Lens Max < 10 Gy; Optic Nerves Max < 35 Gy; Brainstem Max < 54 Gy; Spinal Cord Max < 45 Gy; Kidney V10Gy < 10%; Liver Mean < 20 Gy. All constraints met.
dosimetry.planNotes: Standard risk medulloblastoma, WNT-activated. CSI to 23.4 Gy with involved field boost to posterior fossa to 54 Gy. Vincristine omitted for adult patient. Gapped abutting fields for craniospinal axis to prevent overlap and underdosing, verified by film and calculations. Patient stem cells not collected pre-RT as per discussion with Neuro-Oncology due to WNT-activated subtype and favorable prognosis.

imagingAndReports.summary: Medulloblastoma, Classic Histology, WNT-activated (CTNNB1 mutation positive).

reportDetails.microscopicDescription: Sections show a densely cellular embryonal neoplasm composed of small, round blue cells. Features include scant cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei, and high mitotic activity. Rosettes are present.
reportDetails.molecularInformation: CTNNB1 mutation: Positive (WNT-activated subtype). Monosomy 6: Present.
reportDetails.comment: The histologic and molecular features are diagnostic of WNT-activated medulloblastoma, WHO Grade 4. This subtype is associated with a favorable prognosis.

imagingAndReports.summary: No gross residual disease identified in the posterior fossa. No evidence of leptomeningeal spread.

reportDetails.findings: Post-surgical changes in the cerebellum consistent with resection. No enhancing residual tumor. Ventricular system stable. No hydrocephalus. CSF spaces appear clear.
reportDetails.impression: Post-operative MRI, no gross residual disease of cerebellar medulloblastoma.

imagingAndReports.summary: No evidence of spinal metastases or leptomeningeal dissemination.

reportDetails.findings: Cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine MRI with and without contrast. No enhancing lesions or CSF signal abnormalities suggestive of metastatic disease.
reportDetails.impression: Normal spinal MRI. No evidence of disease dissemination.

imagingAndReports.summary: CSF cytology negative for malignant cells. Normal protein and glucose.

reportDetails.cytology: Negative for malignant cells. No evidence of leptomeningeal seeding.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Emily Roberts (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt seen post-op for cerebellar Medulloblastoma. Reviewed imaging, pathology (WNT-activated, good prognosis). Discussed standard of care adjuvant craniospinal irradiation (CSI) with posterior fossa boost. Explained goals (reduce recurrence risk), procedure, potential side effects (fatigue, myelosuppression, hair loss, potential long-term neurocognitive effects). Patient and parents understand and agree to proceed. Decision made to omit concurrent vincristine for adult patient as per NCCN guidelines. Plan for CT Sim with prone setup for CSI. Discussed potential for stem cell collection if future high-dose chemotherapy is needed, but deferred at this time given WNT-activated favorable prognosis. Sedation for daily treatments was discussed given the patient's age and the need for precise setup and motion management, but patient and parents opted to attempt treatment without it initially, with a plan to re-evaluate if motion becomes an issue.
progressNotes.patientConcerns: Parents inquired about prognosis and school reintegration.
progressNotes.instructionsGiven: Provided patient education materials on RT and Medulloblastoma.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: Adjuvant therapy to prevent recurrence after surgery and address microscopic disease spread along the central nervous system. Emphasized high cure rates for WNT-activated medulloblastoma.
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: Fatigue (common and can be prolonged), hair loss (scalp and spinal field, potentially permanent in some areas), skin redness/dryness/peeling (dermatitis), nausea/vomiting (especially early in treatment), lowered blood counts (myelosuppression), potential long-term neurocognitive effects (memory, processing speed, attention), hearing loss (very low risk with proton therapy or careful photon planning), growth/endocrine issues (long-term monitoring needed), secondary malignancy (very low risk).
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Importance of proper positioning for daily treatment for accuracy. Strict skin care along radiation fields (gentle washing, approved moisturizers, avoid sun exposure, harsh chemicals/friction). Monitoring for signs of infection (fever, chills, sore throat) due to low blood counts and reporting immediately. Reporting any new or worsening neurological symptoms (e.g., vision changes, weakness, balance issues). Discussion of sedation: while not currently used, it was discussed as an option to ensure patient stillness and treatment accuracy given the complexity of craniospinal fields, and will be re-evaluated if needed.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend daily RT appointments without missing fractions if possible. Perform skin care as instructed by therapists/nurses. Maintain good nutrition and hydration. Attend weekly OTVs with physician and nurses, and complete all scheduled lab draws. Report any new or worsening symptoms promptly.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Adhere to Dexamethasone tapering schedule to minimize steroid side effects. Take Ondansetron/Prochlorperazine proactively for nausea as needed.
